bwwExcerpt: Why on earth did anyone think it a good idea to mount a Broadway production of a British farce about a transgender gangster named Waxy Bush who attempts to fix the snooker world tournament-especially one in which all of the characters speak in a mostly unintelligible working-class dialect? Having squirmed without cease through the U.S. premiere of Richard Bean's "The Nap," I'm forced to the conclusion that a not-inconsiderable number of New York theatergoers get a thrill out of hearing the words
